markdownRemark.html:
My internship at Capgemini Invent as a Data Scientist Intern has been a very valuable experience. I had the opportunity to meet many interesting people, motivated, eager to learn, build and tackle all kind of challenges. The mood was always great in the Insight Driven Enterprise team and you had to congratulate the HR teams for their excellent job at recruiting people with that good mindset.

However.

In the open space, a discussion was quite recurrent between Data Scientists. A discussion that would trigger tensions, a discussion that some people were not comfortable with. It all came from a question that no one could really answer, a question lurking in the shadow in everyone's mind that would tickle now and then the paradoxal beings that we are:

What is a Data Scientist ?

Let's put aside the dramatic effects aside and avoid the meta-philosophical discussions that we can be tempted to have around the meaning of life and such. Let's talk concrete stuff. When you dig a bit into from a pragmatic point of view, this question often transforms into another: what is the job of a Data Scientist ?

One can fetch the definition of Data Sciences on Wikipedia seeking for help from the worldwide collaborative intelligence:

Data science is a "concept to unify statistics, data analysis, machine learning and their related methods" in order to "understand and analyze actual phenomena" with data.

This is obviously a good definition since it has been edited over 986 times. Using this definition, and the proposition that Data Scientists are the people doing Data Science, we can infer a definition for Data Scientists, and this will be my own :

Data Scientists make analysis based on data using mathematics, computer sciences and additional knowledge on the business domain.

Okay, I have cheated and changed the last part, inspired by this famous chart. Data Scientists have a goal: do analysis using data. This can be quite simple with only descriptive statistics, a few plots and some common sense. This can be more complex using statistical methods and mathematical modeling to highlight mecanisms. This can be the automation of decision-making processes (thus raising the term Artificial Intelligence) using inference algorithms and Machine Learning. This can be so many different things I am not going to cover them all.

In the end, in order to define what a Data Scientist is, what matters is

  1. the fact that they work on data,
  2. the skillset needed to be a Data Scientist : good fundamentals in mathematics, good skills in computer sciences and good understanding of the business.

This is a nice definition that can be applied to many people who claim to be Data Scientists, but reality is not that simple. In companies, it is not good enough to plot things, the send a Jupyter Notebook or a folder with Python scripts. In the real real life, people want applications. And that is the pain point.
